intro.description: This cheat sheet demonstrates general chemistry (or, more strictly speaking, chemoinformatics) tasks you can do in Bioclipse. These are centered around handling molecular data files and calculating molecular properties.

item.title: Step 0: Prerequisites
item.description: You need the Chemoinformatics feature installed to run this cheat sheet. If you run this sheet from within Bioclipse, you have if this feature already installed.

item.title: Option 1: Draw and Edit single Structures, handle File Formats
item.description: The JChemPaint editor allows graphical viewing and editing of 2D diagrams of chemical structures in various formats. You can also draw new chemical structures from scratch, and save in CML and MDL molfile formats. See help via ? on top of this section for details.

item.title: Option 2: Handle Multiple Structure Files
item.description: Files with multiple structures (MDL SD files, and SMILES files) are handled by the SDF Editor (use ? for details). This editor also offers extraction of files (e.g. single files for editing in JChemPaint). Creation of new SD files can be performed with a New Wizard.

item.title: Option 3: Compare molecules
item.description: You can calculate Tanimoto scores to compare the similarity of molecules against a reference molecule. See ? for details.

item.title: Option 4: Calculate QSAR descriptors
item.description: A wide variety of molecular QSAR descriptors (e.g. XLogP, ALogP, Lipinske Rule of Five, Atomic Polarizability) can be calculated in Bioclipse using the QSAR feature. See ? for details.

item.title: Option 5: Convert file formats
item.description: In order to convert from one file formats to another (e.g. convert a MDL molfile to a CML file), you need to open the file in JChemPaint (double-clicking normally does this) and save it via File->Save As.. in the new format. The new files must have either the .mol or .cml file extension. See ? for details.

item.title: Option 6: Create 2D and 3D coordinates
item.description: You can create 2D and 3D coordinates for molecules (either if they do not yet exist or if there are already some, which means you do a cleanup). Right click on the file and choose "Generate 2D/3D". See ? for details.

item.title: Option 8: Search in External databases
item.description: You can search in a variety of external (EBI) databases File -> New -> Web Services -> Use WSDbfetch Web Service at EBI. See ? for details.

item.title: Option 9: Work with Spectral Data
item.description: If you want to work with spectral data (e. g. view spectra and peak pick them, do a structure elucidation), you should install the Speclipse feature (in case this is not yet the case) via Help -> Software Update -> Speclipse Update Site and read the General Spectrum Cheat Sheet.
